Description: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE FOREST AND PEATLAND MANAGEMENT THROUGHOUT THE TARGET LANDSCAPES, WHICH DIRECTLY RESULTS IN REDUCED DEFORESTATION AND IMPROVED PROTECTION OF THREATENED APE POPULATIONS, WITH ENHANCED GOVERNANCE, INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY, MONITORING, AND COMMUNITY LEADERSHIP ENSURING SUSTAINED DELIVERY OF OUTPUTS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) LANDSCAPE GOVERNANCE STRENGTHENED THROUGH ENHANCED LOCAL STAKEHOLDER COORDINATION AND IMPROVED LOCAL CAPACITY, TO SUCCESSFULLY DELIVER APE CONSERVATION GOALS  (2) LOCAL COMMUNITIES ACHIEVE GREATER AUTONOMY TO EFFECTIVELY MANAGE FORESTS AND DEVELOP INCREASINGLY SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS, DEVELOPING A MORE PRO-CONSERVATION LOCAL SOCIETY  (3) IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO REDUCE AND REVERSE DEFORESTATION IN THE TARGET LANDSCAPES  AND (4) MONITOR APE POPULATIONS AND THREATS THROUGHOUT EACH LANDSCAPE, INTRODUCING INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGIES AND BUILDING LOCAL CAPACITY.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE COMMUNITY PROTECTION SYSTEM FOR ORANGUTANS AND THEIR FOREST HABITAT AROUND THE KETAMBE, SUAQ BELIMBING AND SORAYA RESEARCH STATIONS BY ESTABLISHING AND ENHANCING COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS THAT ENGAGE IN PARTICIPATORY FOREST PATROL AND FOREST RESTORATION. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE,  1  TRAINING OF COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS   2  EQUIP AND SUPPORT COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS BY PROVIDING THE TEAMS WITH BASIC FIELD GEAR SUCH AS TENTS, FIELD CLOTHING, RAINCOATS, GPS UNITS, ETC.   3  COMMUNITY PATROLS AND  REDUCE ILLEGAL ACTIVITY   4  FOREST RESTORATION IN ORANGUTAN HABITAT  AND  5  ORANGUTAN MONITORING IN KETAMBE AND SORAYA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO  1  EXPAND THE MONITORING OF ORANGUTANS IN FOREST PATCHES AND WITHIN OIL PALM PLANTATIONS  DATA WILL BE COLLECTED AND ANALYZED ABOUT ORANGUTAN ECOLOGY IN AGRICULTURAL MOSAIC LANDSCAPES AND HOW THEY USE REFORESTED CORRIDORS  NEW INNOVATIVE APPROACHES WILL BE DESIGNED WITH NEW TECHNOLOGY TO COLLECT INFORMATION ABOUT ORANGUTAN PRESENCE AND SURVIVAL IN AN OIL PALM LANDSCAPE, SUCH AS THE USE OF PASSIVE ACOUSTIC MONITORING TECHNIQUES AND EDNA   2  ENSURE MORE EFFECTIVE LAW ENFORCEMENT, FOR EXAMPLE ASSESSMENT OF ACTUAL CROP DAMAGE BY ORANGUTANS AND PROPOSE MITIGATION TECHNIQUES, WITHIN PLANTATIONS AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF ALL STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT THE PROTECTED AND ENDANGERED STATUS OF THE ORANGUTAN  MINIMIZE THE LOSS OF ORANGUTANS WITHIN PLANTATION  RAISE AWARENESS FOR PEACEFUL COEXISTENCE WITH ORANGUTANS  AND  3  IDENTIFY AND CREATE FOREST CORRIDORS INSIDE OIL PALM PLANTATIONS TO INCREASE NATURAL FOREST COVER AND SUSTAIN ORANGUTAN SURVIVAL IN THIS LANDSCAPE  CREATE AND MAINTAIN FOREST CORRIDORS FOR ORANGUTANS AND BIODIVERSITY

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD ARE TO BE USED TO UNDERSTAND THE ORANGUTAN DYNAMIC IN A LANDSCAPE DOMINATED BY OIL PALM PLANTATIONS, AND PROMOTE PEACEFUL CO EXISTENCE BETWEEN PEOPLE AND ORANGUTANS WITHIN AN OIL PALM LANDSCAPE  PROJECT OBJECTS ARE TO,  1  UNDERSTAND ORANGUTAN DISTRIBUTION WITHIN OIL PALM ESTATES OF LOWER KINABATANGAN,  2  UNDERSTAND THE DYNAMIC OF ORANGUTAN SUB POPULATIONS WITHIN AN OIL PALM DOMINATED LANDSCAPE,  3  DOCUMENT THE IMPACT OF HABITAT FRAGMENTATION OF THE RESIDENTIAL STATUS OF FEMALE ORANGUTANS,  4  CREATE A RESILIENT LANDSCAPE THAT WILL SUSTAIN ORANGUTANS IN THE LONG TERM,  5  ASSESS CROP DAMAGES DUE TO ORANGUTAN PRESENCE, AND,  6  ENSURE A PEACEFUL ACCEPTATANCE OF ORANGUTAN PRESENCE WITHIN THE OIL PALM PLANTATIONS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CHARACTERIZE PARASITE COMMUNITIES IN GREAT APES AND DRIVING FACTORS OF A FATAL CHRONIC WASTING SYNDROME AFFECTING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED MOUNTAIN GORILLAS AND ENDANGERED EASTERN CHIMPANZEES IN BWINDI IMPENETRABLE NATIONAL PARK, UGANDA BY   1  DETERMINING THE PARASITE DIVERSITY AND INFECTION BURDEN IN THE PARK S GREAT APES   2  DETECTING POSSIBLE RESERVOIRS OF ZOONOTIC PARASITES AFFECTING THE PARK S WILDLIFE   3  EVALUATING THE ROLE OF STRONGYLID PARASITES IN THE CLINICAL SYNDROME   4  INVESTIGATING FORCES DRIVING ZOONOTIC PARASITE INFECTIONS IN GREAT APES   5  INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF THE DISEASE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM  AND  6  INCREASING LOCAL COMMUNITIES  AWARENESS OF PATHOGEN TRANSMISSION RISKS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE SURVIVAL OF ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEES IN TANZANIA'S GREATER MAHALE ECOSYSTEM AND PROTECT A KEY HABITAT CORRIDOR BY: (1) EQUIPPING AND TRAINING VILLAGE FOREST SCOUTS INCLUDING THE PROVISION OF GPSS, CAMERAS, BINOCULARS, AND FOOTWEAR; (2) INCREASING VILLAGE CAPACITY TO DERIVE A SUSTAINABLE INCOME FROM VILLAGE FORESTS BY AUGMENTING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY CONSERVATION BANK (COCOBA) MICRO-FINANCE SYSTEMS, DEVELOPING ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS, IMPLEMENTING A CARBON CREDIT INCOME PROJECT, AND PROVIDING GOVERNANCE TRAINING; (3) CONDUCTING BIODIVERSITY SURVEYS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND CORRIDOR USE BY CHIMPANZEES AND OTHER KEY SPECIES; AND (4) CONDUCTING A SOCIO-ECONOMIC SURVEY TO UNDERSTAND DRIVERS OF HUMAN IN-MIGRATION AND ENCROACHMENT ON CHIMPANZEE HABITAT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE STRENGTHENING OF HABITAT CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN THE MOYEN-BAFING AND BADIAR NATIONAL PARKS TO IMPROVE CONDITIONS FOR WEST AFRICAN CHIMPANZEES BY: (1) INCREASING INVOLVEMENT OF LOCAL POPULATIONS IN THE SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES COMMUNICATIONS, STRENGTHENING LOCAL GOVERNANCE STRUCTURES, AND IMPLEMENTING PARTICIPATIVE CORRIDOR BOUNDARY IDENTIFICATION; AND (2) RESTORING HABITAT CONNECTIVITY BETWEEN IDENTIFIED CHIMPANZEE HOTSPOTS IN THE MOYEN-BAFING AND BADIAR NATIONAL PARKS LANDSCAPE THROUGH CAMERA-TRAP MONITORING OF CHIMPANZEES, ESTABLISHING LAND COVER AND LAND USE BASELINE DATA, REHABILITATING KEY FOREST HABITATS THROUGH NATURAL REGENERATION, AND ESTABLISHING FIREBREAKS AND A FIRE MANAGEMENT PLAN TO ACCELERATE THE REESTABLISHMENT OF DEGRADED HABITAT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO GENERATE CRITICAL INFORMATION ON THE ECOLOGY AND BIOLOGY OF A BACTERIUM RESPONSIBLE FOR AN EMERGING AND POSSIBLY ZOONOTIC DISEASE (EPIZOOTIC NEUROLOGIC AND GASTROENTERIC SYNDROME, ENGS) KILLING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEES AT A SANCTUARY IN SIERRA LEONE, AND TO ASSESS THE THREAT TO WILD APES BY: (1) CONDUCTING ECOLOGICAL STUDIES TO DETERMINE THE SOURCE OF INFECTION, EXPLAIN SEASONAL PATTERNS OF MORTALITY, AND IDENTIFY CRITICAL MANAGEMENT-RELATED INTERVENTIONS FOR STOPPING THE SPREAD OF THE DISEASE; (2) DETERMINING HOW WIDESPREAD THE BACTERIUM AND SYNDROME ARE IN EQUATORIAL AFRICAN SANCTUARIES AND IN THE WILD; AND (3) DETERMINING OPTIMAL GROWTH CONDITIONS FOR THE BACTERIUM IN THE LABORATORY TO FACILITATE FUTURE INVESTIGATIONS OF TREATMENTS AND PREVENTIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE PROTECTION OF LOMA MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK'S ENDANGERED CHIMPANZEES BY: (1) CONDUCTING SURVEYS TO ESTIMATE CHIMPANZEE ABUNDANCE, UNDERSTAND POPULATION DYNAMICS, AND IDENTIFY CULTURAL TRAITS; (2) CONDUCTING FECAL ANALYSIS AND BOTANICAL SURVEYS TO DETERMINE CHIMPANZEE DIETARY HABITS, AND RESOURCE NEEDS AND USE; (3) USING BOTANICAL SURVEYS, SATELLITE IMAGERY AND GROUND-TRUTHING TO MAP CHIMPANZEE HABITAT; (4) RESTORING THAT HABITAT THROUGH REFORESTATION WITH KEY TREE SPECIES; (5) IMPROVING BIOMONITORING THROUGH INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY MONITORS AND EXPANDING THEIR TRAINING; (6) CONDUCTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IN 14 SCHOOLS AND INTRODUCING A ROOTS & SHOOTS PROGRAM FOR REGIONAL YOUTH; (7) IMPROVING UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL ECONOMIES THROUGH A SOCIOECONOMIC STUDY AND LAND USE PLANNING; AND PROMOTING A SHIFT TO MORE ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY LIVELIHOODS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT DISEASE TESTING OF CAPTIVE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED GRAUER'S GORILLAS AT THE GRACE CENTRE IN THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE CONGO TO IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS SUITABLE FOR REINTRODUCTION TO THE WILD TO REINFORCE A WANING BUT IMPORTANT SUB-POPULATION OF GORILLAS IN THE VIRUNGA NATIONAL PARK'S MT. TCHABIRIMU.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE LOSS AND DEGRADATION OF CHIMPANZEE HABITAT IN THE UGANDAN ALBERTINE RIFT BY: (1) RESTORING CHIMPANZEE HABITAT IN TWO FOREST RESERVES THROUGH REPLANTING AT LEAST 100 HA OF NATIVE TREE SPECIES; (2) MONITORING HABITAT RECOVERY AND CHIMPANZEE USE BY COMMUNITY FOREST MONITORS; (3) OPERATIONALIZING A PARTNER COORDINATION PLATFORM TO PROMOTE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION STRATEGIC ACTION PLAN; (4) ENGAGING PRIVATE COMPANIES AND DEVELOPING PARTNERSHIPS TO SUPPORT CHIMP CONSERVATION; (5) STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION PROGRAMS THROUGH SUPPORT OF COMMUNITY ENTERPRISES, OUTREACH EDUCATION, AND CONSULTATIVE MEETINGS BETWEEN COMMUNITIES AND PROTECTED AREA AUTHORITIES; AND (6) ESTABLISHING A COMMUNITY ASSOCIATION-MANAGED HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT RESILIENCE FUND TO COMPENSATE VICTIMS FOR NEGATIVE IMPACTS SUFFERED LOSS DUE TO CHIMPANZEES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE RAPID INCREASE OF THREATS TO WESTERN CHIMPANZEE POPULATIONS AND OTHER BIODIVERSITY IN HAUT NIGER NATIONAL PARK, GUINEA BY (1) PROTECTING RELEASED AND FREE-RANGING CHIMPANZEES, AND MINIMIZING HUMAN-CHIMPANZEE CONTACT, THROUGH PHYSICAL STAFF PRESENCE AND ACTIVE MONITORING; (2) EXPANDING AN ONGOING CAMERA TRAP PROJECT TO COVER 100% OF THE PARK'S MAFOU CORE AREA; (3) INCREASING AWARENESS AND SUPPORT FOR CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION BY DISSEMINATING CAMERA TRAP DATA IN SCIENTIFIC PUBLICATIONS AND TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES, EXPANDING THE EDUCATION FOR CONSERVATION PROGRAM, AND AIRING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING ON LOCAL RADIO; (4) REDUCING ANTHROPOGENIC PRESSURES ON THE PARK BY APPLYING RESULTS OF A SOCIOECONOMIC STUDY TO GUIDE DEVELOPMENT OF ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS BEEKEEPING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE SECOND LARGEST POPULATION OF ENDANGERED WESTERN CHIMPANZEES IN LIBERIA THROUGH GAZETTEMENT OF THE KRAHN-BASSA PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA (KBPPA) AS LIBERIA'S LARGEST NATIONAL PARK BY: (1) INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING TEAMS, IMPLEMENTING SMART DATA COLLECTION, AND SHARING OF INFORMATION WITH THE PARK AUTHORITIES; (2) INCREASING LOCAL COMMUNITIES' AWARENESS OF HUMAN-CHIMP CONFLICT AND HOW TO AVOID IT; AND (3) IMPROVING COMMUNITY ECOMONITORING COLLABORATION WITH LIBERIA'S WILDLIFE CRIME TASK FORCE THROUGH INCREASED TRAINING, COMMUNICATION, AND JOINT MONITORING ACTIVITIES.
PROTECTING BORNEAN ORANGUTANS, WHITE-BEARDED GIBBONS, AND THE ABBOTT'S GRAY GIBBONS THROUGH A COMMUNITY-LED APPROACH IN WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE COEXISTENCE BETWEEN HUMANS AND ENDANGERED EASTERN CHIMPANZEES IN WESTERN UGANDA'S BUDONGO-BUGOMA LANDSCAPE BY: (1) IMPROVING MONITORING OF HUMAN-CHIMPANZEE CONFLICT; (2) INCREASING AWARENESS AND CAPACITY OF PRIVATE FOREST OWNERS ASSOCIATIONS TO MITIGATE HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT, INCLUDING USE OF UNPALATABLE CROPS AND LIVE FENCES; AND (3) ESTABLISHING VILLAGE SAVINGS AND LOAN ASSOCIATIONS TO PROVIDE A SUSTAINABLE, COMMUNITY-DRIVEN FINANCE MECHANISM TO SUPPORT HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT MITIGATION ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE REINTRODUCTION AND PROTECTION OF NEW, FULLY WILD, VIABLE POPULATIONS OF BORNEAN ORANGUTANS, BY EFFECTIVELY EXPANDING REINTRODUCTION AND POST-RELEASE MONITORING, AS WELL AS STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITIES OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND NEIGHBORING COMMUNITIES TO CONSERVE THE NEWLY-ESTABLISHED ORANGUTAN POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITAT. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) EXPAND ORANGUTAN REINTRODUCTION AND POST-RELEASE MONITORING IN THE BUKIT BATIKAP PROTECTION FOREST; AND (2) ENHANCE THE CAPACITIES OF LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY-LEVEL STAKEHOLDERS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT ORANGUTAN AND ORANGUTAN HABITAT CONSERVATION INTERVENTIONS IN BATIKAP.
FOREST DEPARTMENT-COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIP TO IMPROVE PROTECTION OF WESTERN HOOLOCK GIBBONS HOOLOCK IN JEYPORE, RF, INDIA -PHASE VIII
CONSERVATION OF ORANGUTANS AT THE CORE HABITATS OF BATANG AI-LANJAK-ENTIMAU (BALE) LANDSCAPE IN SARAWAK, MALAYSIA (PHASE TWO)
PROTECTING APE HABITAT IN TWO CRITICAL RAINFOREST LANDSCAPES IN SOUTHERN BORNEO
USING HEALTHCARE AND CONSERVATION INCENTIVES TO PROTECT ORANGUTAN HABITAT IN INDONESIAN BORNEO -- CYCLE 12: RESTORING RAINFOREST ECOSYSTEMS AND SUPPORTING SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS
SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN (PONGO ABELII) REINTRODUCTION, POPULATION RESEARCH AND ENHANCING COMMUNITY CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP - ACEH, INDONESIA

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO (1) APPLY THE USE OF DRONE TECHNOLOGY, INCLUDING NEWLY AVAILABLE THERMAL DRONES, TO ASSESS ORANGUTAN POPULATIONS, LOCATE INDIVIDUAL ANIMALS AND ASSESS CANOPY TEMPERATURE, AND BUILD A PHOTOGRAPHIC DATABASE OF ORANGUTAN NESTS FROM A DRONE'S PERSPECTIVE; PILOT THE USE OF THERMAL-EQUIPPED DRONES AS A METHOD FOR LOCATING ORANGUTANS; IMPLEMENT THE USE OF THERMAL-EQUIPPED DRONES TO RAPIDLY ASSESS ORANGUTAN PRESENCE IN PROTECTED CUSTOMARY FOREST AREAS; AND ASSESS CANOPY TEMPERATURE USING THERMAL-EQUIPPED DRONES AS A MEASURE OF DEGRADATION AND FIRE RISK; (2) DETERMINE AND MONITOR LEVELS OF BIODIVERSITY AND ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCE IN PRIMARY, DEGRADED AND CUSTOMARY FOREST HABITATS; INVESTIGATE DIFFERENCES IN BIODIVERSITY AND ORANGUTAN BEHAVIOR BETWEEN FOREST HABITATS THROUGH CAMERA TRAPPING; EXPAND BIO-ACOUSTIC MONITORING IN DEGRADED AND PRIMARY HABITATS; INVESTIGATE DIFFERENCES IN PHENOLOGY OF TREES AND LIANAS IN PRIMARY, DISTURBED AND CUSTOMARY FORESTS; DETERMINE DIFFERENCES IN RAINFALL, TEMPERATURE, HUMIDITY AND SOLAR RADIATION ACROSS PRIMARY AND DISTURBED FORESTS AS A MEASURE OF ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCE AND AN INDICATOR OF FOREST FIRE RISK; (3) UNDERSTAND THE IMPACT OF HUMAN DISTURBANCE, ACTIVITY AND PROXIMITY ON ORANGUTAN BEHAVIOR, DIET, AND HEALTH IN DIFFERENT FOREST TYPES PRESENT IN THE GUNUNG PALUNG NATIONAL PARK (GPNP) LANDSCAPE; DETERMINE INDIVIDUAL IDENTITY OF ORANGUTANS UTILIZING PRIMARY, DEGRADED AND CUSTOMARY FOREST HABITATS; ESTABLISH A SEMI-PERMANENT CAMP AT THE RANGKONG RESEARCH SITE; DETERMINE DIFFERENCES IN ORANGUTAN RANGE USE AND BEHAVIOR IN DEGRADED VS. PRIMARY FOREST TYPES; DETERMINE DIFFERENCES IN ORANGUTAN DIET IN PRIMARY, DEGRADED AND CUSTOMARY FORESTS; MEASURE HEALTH AND PARASITE LOAD OF ORANGUTANS FOUND IN THE RANGKONG AND CABANG PANTI SITES; (4) ASSIST THE TANJUNG GUNUNG COMMUNITY DECREASE THEIR DEPENDENCE ON ENVIRONMENTALLY DESTRUCTIVE ACTIVITIES, SWITCHING TO MORE SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOODS AND BECOMING ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS; SUPPORTING NEW FARMING METHODS TO OPTIMIZE LAND USE AND MITIGATE THE NEED FOR ADDITIONAL FOREST CLEARING; MITIGATING WILD FIRES AND REFORESTING AN AREA DIRECTLY ADJACENT TO GPNP THAT IS IN DANGER OF ANNUAL FIRES; AND (5) CUSTOMARY FORESTS ARE ABLE TO MANAGE THEIR LAND SUSTAINABLY AND PREVENT ORANGUTAN-HUMAN CONFLICT; DETERMINE ORANGUTAN POPULATION STATUS IN CUSTOMARY FORESTS IN COLLABORATION WITH CUSTOMARY FOREST MANAGEMENT BOARD (LPHD); REDUCE IMPACT OF WILD FIRES ON CUSTOMARY FORESTS AND THE SURROUNDING AREAS IN COLLABORATION IN LPHD BY TRAINING THEM IN FIREFIGHTING AND FIRE PREVENTION AS WELL AS PROVIDE THEM WITH MORE FIREFIGHTING EQUIPMENT; MITIGATE ILLEGAL ACTIVITY IN PROTECTED CUSTOMARY FORESTS, BY PROVIDING THEM WITH SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROL TRAINING AND IMPLEMENTATION AND MONTHLY REPORTING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE ORANGUTAN CONSERVATION PRACTICE THROUGH SPATIALLY SPECIFIC, DATA-DRIVEN ORANGUTAN INVESTMENT STANDARDS, ORANGUTAN MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND SITE-SPECIFIC HUMAN-ORANGUTAN COEXISTENCE SOLUTIONS BASED ON COMMUNITY NEEDS. OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: (1) INFLUENCE THE FINANCIAL SECTOR TO ADOPT OR STRENGTHEN RISK ASSESSMENT POLICIES FOR ORANGUTAN CONSERVATION, AND BEST PRACTICES FOR MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF FUNDED PROJECTS; (2) IMPROVE STAKEHOLDER KNOWLEDGE OF SPATIALLY SPECIFIC ORANGUTAN CONSERVATION PRIORITY ACTIONS AND METAPOPULATION MANAGEMENT, AND ENGAGE STAKEHOLDERS IN DESIGNING AND IMPLEMENTING SOLUTIONS; (3) DETERMINE LOCAL COMMUNITY NEEDS AND BEST STRATEGIC INTERVENTIONS TO ENABLE BEHAVIOR CHANGES THAT WILL FOSTER PEACEFUL COEXISTENCE WITH ORANGUTANS; AND (4) FACILITATE IMPLEMENTATION OF EFFECTIVELY MONITORED, DATA-DRIVEN HUMAN-ORANGUTAN COEXISTENCE SOLUTIONS INFORMED BY FINDINGS ON CONSERVATION EFFECTIVENESS, METAPOPULATION MANAGEMENT AND COMMUNITY NEEDS.

STRENGTHENING PROTECTION OF NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN WHITE-CHEEKED GIBBONS IN A SITE OF GLOBAL SIGNIFICANCE, THE NAM KADING NATIONAL PROTECTED AREA AND IMPROVING KNOWLEDGE OF THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF BOTH SPECIES IN BOLIKHAMXAY PROVINCE, LAO PDR
STRENGTHENING LOCAL CAPACITY FOR GIBBON CONSERVATION IN CAMBODIA
A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO THE CONSERVATION OF PONGO PYGMAEUS IN WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA.
BEST PRACTICE GUIDELINES FOR GREAT APE CONSERVATION: CRITICAL UPDATESTO REFLECT CHANGING CONTEXTS AND ADVANCES IN SCIENTIFIC KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNOLOGY
SECURING THE FUTURE OF NORTHERN VIETNAM'S CRITICALLY ENDANGERED GIBBONS
PROTECTION OF SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN (PONGO ABELII) POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS IN KETAMBE, SORAYA AND SUAQ RESEARCH STATIONS IN WESTERN LEUSER ECOSYSTEM, ACEH, INDONESIA
COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION OF JAVAN GIBBON (HYLOBATES MOLOCH) IN CENTRAL JAVA, INDONESIA.
RECOVERING THE LAST VIABLE POPULATION OF ENDANGERED WHITE-HANDED GIBBONS IN NAM POUI NATIONAL PROTECTED AREA, LAO PDR
ENHANCING SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON CONSERVATION THROUGH IMPROVED PROTECTION AND RESEARCH IN BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN NATIONAL PARK.
STRENGTHENING CONSERVATION OF THE ENDANGERED PILEATED GIBBON (HYLOBATES PILEATUS) IN PREY LANG WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, CAMBODIA
SECURING CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION IN THE MAHALE - TONGWE WEST CORRIDOR
REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - CONSERVING THE ENDANGERED PILEATED GIBBON (HYLOBATES PILEAUS) IN PREY LANG WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, CAMBODIA
REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - LAR GIBBON PROTECTION IN THAILAND'S WESTERN FOREST COMPLEX
REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - NORTHERN PLAINS OF CAMBODIA PILEATED GIBBON CONSERVATION PROJECT: PHASE 7
REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - STRENGTHENING AND FURTHER EXPAND THE COMMUNITY LED PATROLLING MODEL TO PROTECT NORTHERN WHITE-CHEEKED GIBBON POPULATIONS IN LAO
REPLACEMENT AWARDS FOR FY2019 - CONSERVATION OF CHIMPANZEES IN SOUTHERN TANGANYIKA ECOSYSTEM

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO PROTECT CHIMPANZEES OF THE WEST NIMBA MOUNTAINS THROUGH BIOMONITORING AND REDUCING CHIMPANZEE POACHING. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) ESTABLISHING BASELINE CHIMPANZEE POACHING DATA; 2) IDENTIFY, EDUCATING AND RECRUITING AT LEAST 50% OF FULL-TIME HUNTERS INTO A COMMUNITY-BASED RANGER MONITORING PROGRAM; 3) IMPLEMENTING AN INNOVATIVE CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND AWARENESS PROGRAM AND MOTIVATING CONSERVATION SENSITIVE LOCAL BEHAVIORS; 4) TRAINING COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT BIO-MONITORING, INCLUDING CAMERA-TRAPPING; 5) ESTABLISHING PERMANENT TRANSECTS BASED ON INITIAL SURVEYS; AND 6) MAPPING CHIMPANZEE PRESENCE AND ASSOCIATED THREATS USING THE SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL (SMART) PROGRAM.

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE LONG-TERM CONSERVATION OF HOOLOCK GIBBON AND ITS HABITAT BY ENGENDERING WELL-TRAINED, SKILLED AND MOTIVATED FRONTLINE STAFF AND CONSERVATION EDUCATORS.  THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) TRAIN FOREST FRONTLINE STAFF ON HOOLOCK GIBBON PROTECTION,  (2) TRAIN EDUCATORS ON HOOLOCK GIBBON CONSERVATION, AND, (3) EVALUATE THE IMPACT OF THE ABOVE TRAINING PROGRAMS THREE OR SIX MONTHS AFTER THE TRAINING PROGRAM.  A NETWORK WILL BE CREATED WITH THE PARTICIPANTS, WHICH WILL BE MONITORED BY ZOO OUTREACH ORGANIZATION AND THE FOREST DEPARTMENT.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ENSURE A LONG-TERM CONSERVATION OF HOOLOCK GIBBON AND ITS HABITATS IN NAGALAND BY PRODUCING A GROUP OF TRAINED, SKILLED AND MOTIVATED FOREST GUARDS WHO CAN TAKE UP THE DIFFICULT TASK OF PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION BY INVOLVING COMMUNITY AS GIBBON AMBASSADORS LAYING A FOUNDATION FOR APE CONSERVATION IN NAGALAND. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) EDUCATE, EXPOSE AND INCULCATE INTEREST THROUGH VARIOUS METHODS IN FOREST GUARDS TO PROTECT HOOLOCK GIBBON HABITATS IN NAGALAND AND TO EDUCATE THEM ABOUT GLOBAL, NATIONAL AND LOCAL IMPORTANCE OF THE SPECIES; (2) TRAIN FOREST GUARDS TO IDENTIFY THE DIFFERENT PRIMATE SPECIES AND ALSO TO CLASSIFY INDIVIDUALS BASED ON AGE AND SEX TO FACILITATE INDIVIDUAL IDENTIFICATION TO MAINTAIN INDIVIDUAL HISTORIES; (3) TEACH AND TRAIN THE FOREST GUARDS ABOUT GENERAL PRIMATE SURVEY, HOOLOCK GIBBON POPULATION ESTIMATES AND THEIR PRESENT STATUS; AND, (4) PROVIDE LEGAL PROVISIONS CONCERNING WILDLIFE ACT AND WILDLIFE LAWS TO CONTAIN WILDLIFE CRIMES.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE THE GUNUNG NANING PROTECTED FOREST FOR BIODIVERSITY AND PEOPLE. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) COMMUNITY-BASED FOREST PATROL TEAM ENGAGED IN SITE-BASED PROTECTION UTILIZING SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORT TOOL (SMART) TO MEASURE AND MONITOR ACTIVITIES IN GUNUNG NANING PROTECTED FOREST; (2) CONSERVATION COOPERATIVES KICK-STARTED TO REDUCE INEQUALITIES AND PROMOTE SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT IN RURAL BUFFER ZONE COMMUNITIES; (3) CONSERVATION AUDIT AND BUY-BACK PROGRAM PROVIDE INCENTIVES FOR VILLAGES HONORING THEIR CONSERVATION PLEDGE; (4) IMPROVED LAND MANAGEMENT THROUGH ORGANIC FARMING INTENSIFICATION / TRAINING AND AGROFORESTRY; AND, (5)REDUCED INEQUALITIES FOR WOMEN AND YOUTH THROUGH LITERACY PROGRAM AND HEALTH AWARENESS PROGRAMS

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE A TIME AND COST EFFICIENT METHOD TO COUNT ORANGUTAN NESTS ON IMAGES OBTAINED WITH DRONES. THIS METHOD WILL THEN BE IMPLEMENTED ON A WEBSITE WHICH WILL BE MAINTAINED BY LIVERPOOL JOHN MOORES UNIVERSITY AND PRACTITIONERS WILL BE ABLE TO UPLOAD THEIR DRONE DATA AND HAVE THESE ANALYZED FOR FREE. STEPS INCLUDE: (1) DATA COLLECTION/LABELLING: PREVIOUSLY COLLECTED DATA WILL BE UTILIZED FOR TRAINING; (2) MODEL TRAINING; (3) TESTING AND VALIDATION: THE 20,000 IMAGES USED DURING TRAINING WILL BE SPLIT INTO TRAINING/VALIDATION/TEST SETS;  (4) WEB DEPLOYMENT; (5) ONGOING NETWORK AND CLASSIFICATION MODEL OPTIMISATION: THE WEBSITE WILL BE USED BY THE ORANGUTAN CONSERVATION COMMUNITY CHECK THE OVERALL PERFORMANCE OF THE BETA MODEL WHILE PROVIDING A FEEDBACK MECHANISM FOR ANY MISCLASSIFICATIONS, WHICH WILL BE USED TO INTERACTIVELY RETRAIN THE MODEL ONCE ENOUGH SAMPLES HAVE BEEN OBTAINED; AND, (6) DISSEMINATION WORKSHOPS: TO DISSEMINATE THE DATA ANALYSES METHODS, THE FREE WEBSITE WHERE PEOPLE CAN UPLOAD ORANGUTAN NEST IMAGES, AND TO PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS ABOUT THE BEST WAY TO COLLECT ORANGUTAN NEST DATA WITH DRONES THERE WILL BE TWO WORKSHOPS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE CONSERVATION OF SIAMANGS AND AGILE GIBBONS (HYLOBATIDAE) IN INDONESIA BY ESTABLISHING A SMALL FACILITY IN BENGKULU, SUMATRA FOR FINAL REHABILITATION OF TRAFFICKED ANIMALS LEADING TO RELEASE.  PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) DEVELOPMENT OF RECEIVING CENTER IN BENGKULU, SUMATRA FOR FINAL REHABILITATION AND RELEASE OF TRAFFICKED SIAMANGS AND AGILE GIBBONS RELOCATED FROM JAVA, AND, (2) RAISING AWARENESS AMONGST LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN BENGKULU, SUMATRA OF THE NEED FOR CONSERVATION OF SIAMANGS/AGILE GIBBONS, AND THE NEED FOR ERADICATING POACHING AND ANIMAL TRAFFICKING.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND SUSTAIN THE POPULATION OF ORANGUTANS THROUGH THE CONSERVATION OF THE CORE HABITATS OF BATANG AI-LANJAK-ENTIMAU (BALE) LANDSCAPE AND THEIR SURROUNDING AREAS, IN SARAWAK, MALAYSIA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) OBTAIN AN ESTIMATE OF ORANGUTAN POPULATION SIZE AT THE BATANG AI NATIONAL PARK, AND, (2) PROVIDE ENFORCEMENT SUPPORT TO MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES, VIA SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL (SMART) PATROLS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS CONSERVE GIBBONS IN CAMBODIA. WILDLIFE ALLIANCE WILL, (1) ENGAGE LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN ENVIRONMENTAL LAW ENFORCEMENT AND IN-SITU HABITAT PROTECTION OF CRITICALLY PILEATED GIBBON HABITAT IN THE CARDAMOM MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK, (2) DELIVER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IN AREAS WHERE GIBBONS LIVE TO BUILD SUPPORT FOR THEIR CONSERVATION, AND, (3) REINTRODUCE GIBBONS INTO FORESTS SURROUNDING ICONIC TEMPLES OF ANGKOR WAT, USING ANIMALS CONFISCATED FROM ILLEGAL WILDLIFE TRADE OR CAPTIVE BRED ANIMALS, BORN TO RESCUED GIBBONS.

TO PROTECT THE SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN POPULATION STRONGHOLD IN THE SINGKIL WILDLIFE SANCTUARY AND TO AVOID THE DEGRADATION OF IMPORTANT PEAT SWAMPS TO AVOID CARBON EMISSIONS, WCS WILL IMPROVE AND STRENGTHEN PROTECTION AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF SINGKIL WILDLIFE SANCTUARY THROUGH HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT MITIGATION ACTIVITIES. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: (1) REDUCING FOREST ENCROACHMENT, ILLEGAL LOGGING, AND OTHER THREATS IN KEY ORANGUTAN HABITAT IN SINGKIL WILDLIFE SANCTUARY, AND, (2) MITIGATING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICTS (PARTICULARLY WITH ORANGUTAN) AROUND SINGKIL WILDLIFE SANCTUARY AND INCREASE AWARENESS OF THE COMMUNITY ON THE IMPORTANCE OF SINGKIL AS AN ORANGUTAN HABITAT.

THE ROVING GIBBON PATROL UNITS (RGPUS) INVOLVES LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN FOREST PATROLLING,  ORGANIZED ANTI-POACHING PATROLLING IN AN AREA THAT IS LARGELY A RESERVE FOREST AND NOT YET FULLY A PROTECTED AREA, WITH THE FLEXIBILITY OF THE UNITS TO MOVE BETWEEN CAMPS AS NECESSARY AND IN RESPONSE TO CHANGING THREAT PERCEPTIONS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) CONTINUE THE OPERATIONS OF THE THREE ROVING GIBBON AND WILDLIFE PATROL UNITS COMPRISING OF 3 COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN EACH GROUP AND HEADED BY A FOREST GUARD IN EACH GROUP, AND, (2) IMPLEMENT SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) PATROLLING PROTOCOLS, I.E., SYSTEMATICALLY RECORD PATROL DETAILS AND PRODUCE MONTHLY REPORTS AND PLAN FUTURE PATROLS USING THESE REPORTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO UNDERSTAND THE ORANGUTAN DYNAMIC IN A LANDSCAPE DOMINATED BY OIL PALM PLANTATIONS, AND PROMOTE PEACEFUL CO-EXISTENCE BETWEEN PEOPLE AND ORANGUTANS WITHIN AN OIL PALM LANDSCAPE. PROJECT OBJECTS ARE TO, (1) UNDERSTAND ORANGUTAN DISTRIBUTION WITHIN OIL PALM ESTATES OF LOWER KINABATANGAN, (2) UNDERSTAND THE DYNAMIC OF ORANGUTAN SUB-POPULATIONS WITHIN AN OIL PALM DOMINATED LANDSCAPE, (3) DOCUMENT THE IMPACT OF HABITAT FRAGMENTATION OF THE RESIDENTIAL STATUS OF FEMALE ORANGUTANS, (4) CREATE A RESILIENT LANDSCAPE THAT WILL SUSTAIN ORANGUTANS IN THE LONG TERM, (5) ASSESS CROP DAMAGES DUE TO ORANGUTAN PRESENCE, AND, (6) ENSURE A PEACEFUL ACCEPTATANCE OF ORANGUTAN PRESENCE WITHIN THE OIL PALM PLANTATIONS.

THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO DETERMINE IF PLASMODIUM SPP. IS INVOLVED AS A CAUSATIVE AGENT OF SOME OF THE FEBRILE ILLNESSES IN ORANGUTANS, AND IF OCCURRENCE OF DISEASE, AS WELL AS TRANSMISSION AND INCIDENCE RATES OF THESE PATHOGENS, ARE ASSOCIATED WITH SPECIFIC RISK FACTORS PRESENT AT RESCUE AND REHABILITATION CENTERS (RRC) AS WELL AS IN ALTERED WILD ENVIRONMENTS. THE OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) IDENTIFY AND CHARACTERIZE DIFFERENT PLASMODIUM SPECIES AND OTHER POTENTIAL CAUSATIVE AGENTS OF FEBRILE ILLNESSES IN ORANGUTANS, (2) COLLECT BASELINE EPIDEMIOLOGICAL DATA OF PLASMODIUM SPP., (3) ASSESS THE RISK AND SUBSEQUENTLY DESIGN HEALTH INTERVENTIONS AT IARI RRC, AND, (4) DEVELOP EPIDEMIOLOGICAL MODELS OF PLASMODIUM SPP. THAT CAN BE USED FOR ADOPTING CONSERVATION POLICIES AND STRATEGIES TO REDUCE THE POTENTIAL OF DISEASE RISK IN WILD POPULATIONS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT IS TO CONSERVE AND MAINTAIN THE NATURAL ORANGUTAN HABITAT IN BORNEO THROUGH HEALTHCARE AND CONSERVATION INCENTIVES AND INCREASE MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF THESE PROGRAMS. IN THIS PROJECT THE PLAN IS TO EXPAND FOREST GUARDIANSHIP DUTIES TO INCLUDE REFORESTATION ACTIVITIES, REFOREST ADDITIONAL CRITICAL HABITAT ALONG THE CURRENT WILDLIFE CORRIDORS IN GUNUNG PALUNG NATIONAL PARK, ESTABLISH A MEDICAL HEALTHCARE NON-CASH PAYMENT SYSTEM WITH TREE SEEDLINGS FOR COMMUNITIES IN AND AROUND BUKIT BAKA BUKIT RAYA NATIONAL PARK, AND, ENHANCE AND EXPAND OUR BIOMONITORING AND RESEARCH EFFORTS AT OUR PROGRAM SITES IN BOTH PARKS.  PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) EXPANDING THE DUTIES OF FOREST GUARDIANS TO INCLUDE REFORESTATION EFFORTS, (2) MANAGING SEEDLING NURSERIES AND FURTHER REFORESTATION SITE MAINTENANCE AT LAMAN SATONG AND SEDAHAN WILDLIFE CORRIDOR, (3) BEGIN A NON-CASH PAYMENT PROGRAM FOR HEALTHCARE IN AND AROUND BUKIT BAKA BUKIT RAYA NATIONAL PARK (BBBR) BY ALLOWING MIDWIVES CLINIC PATIENTS  AND MOBILE CLINIC PATIENTS TO PAY FOR MEDICAL HEALTHCARE WITH TREE SEEDLINGS, AND, (4) DESIGNING AND CONDUCTING BIOMONITORING AND RESEARCH.

THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS TO UNDERSTAND THE ORANGUTAN'S USE OF DEGRADED HABITAT BY ESTABLISHING A SECONDARY RESEARCH FOCUS IN THE ANTHROPOGENICALLY DISTURBED PART OF THE FOREST THAT EXISTS BETWEEN THE TRANSMIGRANT VILLAGE OF TANJUNG GUNUNG AND THE OUTER BOUNDARIES OF THE CABANG RESEARCH STATION IN THE GUNUNG PALUNG LANDSCAPE AND THROUGH THE FOLLOWING GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: (1) DETERMINE LEVELS OF HABITAT DISRUPTION, PLANT SPECIES DISTRIBUTION AND DENSITY AND LEVELS OF BIODIVERSITY IN DEGRADED VS. PRIMARY HABITAT, AND ESTABLISH BIO-ACOUSTIC MONITORING IN THE RANGKONG AND CABANG PANTI SITES; (2) MONITOR ORANGUTAN HABITAT USE AND DIET IN AN ANTHROPOGENICALLY DISTURBED HABITAT; (3)  ASSESS POPULATION VIABILITY AND HEALTH STATUS OF ORANGUTANS ACROSS THE GPNP LANDSCAPE, AND COMPARE THE RESULTS FROM THIS STUDY WITH PAST RESULTS TO UNDERSTAND HOW ANTHROPOGENIC FACTORS MAY AFFECT ORANGUTAN HEALTH. GENETIC STUDIES WILL BE CARRIED OUT TO DETERMINE IF ORANGUTANS FROM THE PRIMARY FOREST ARE USING THE DEGRADED HABITATS; AND, (4) LEVELS OF ORANGUTAN-HUMAN CONFLICT THROUGH SURVEYS WILL BE DETERMINED IN VILLAGES SURROUNDING THE PARK AND SUCCESS AT ACHIEVING AWARENESS OF ORANGUTAN-HUMAN CONFLICT BY LOCAL COMMUNITIES WILL BE ASSESSED. THERE WILL AWARENESS RAISING PROGRAMS THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TO REMOTE VILLAGES, RADIO PROGRAMS AND PRINT AND SOCIAL MEDIA.

THE PROJECT GOAL IS TO SECURE THE BIODIVERSITY VALUES OF PMNP WITH A FOCUS ON THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED NORTHERN WHITE-CHEEKED GIBBON (NOMASCUS LEUCOGENYS) VIA STRENGTHENING THE 'NO KILL' ZONES AND RELATED LOCAL CAPACITY. THE PROJECT'S OVERARCHING VISION IS TO ESTABLISH THE FIRST EVIDENCE-BASED CONSERVATION PROJECT IN VIETNAM THAT DEMONSTRATES HOW RANGER-BASED PATROLLING IN COMBINATION WITH COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACHES TO PREVENTING WILDLIFE CRIME ' BASED ON SOUND CRIMINOLOGICAL SCIENCE ' CAN LEAD TO QUANTIFIED RECOVERY OF PRIORITY SPECIES.  THE PROJECT'S OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) ACCURATELY ESTIMATE THE GIBBON POPULATION AND MAP ITS DISTRIBUTION INSIDE PU MAT NATIONAL PARK, (2) PROFESSIONALIZE THE COMMUNITY-BASED SNARE REMOVAL AND GIBBON MONITORING TEAMS, AND THEIR USE OF SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL), (3) INTRODUCE SITUATIONAL CRIME PREVENTION TO FURTHER REDUCE ILLEGAL ACTIVITY INSIDE THE NATIONAL PARK, AND, (4) IMPROVE LOCAL CAPACITY FOR PROTECTED AREA MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING.

THE PROJECT'S PURPOSE IS TO STABILIZE AND INCREASE THE LAST VIABLE POPULATION OF NOMASCUS CONCOLOR IN VIETNAM. THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO IMPROVE TRANSBOUNDARY COOPERATION FOR GIBBON CONSERVATION, SUPPORT THE OPERATIONALIZING OF THE CONSERVATION ACTION PLAN IN VIETNAM, WHICH INCLUDES FILLING GAPS IN EXISTING KNOWLEDGE OF THE N. CONCOLOR ECOLOGY, AND REPLICATE THE SUSTAINABLE FINANCE MECHANISM ' ALREADY DEVELOPED WITH SUPPORT FROM USFWS ' TO ADDITIONAL SITES WITHIN THIS LANDSCAPE. THE PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) EXPAND PAYMENT FOR ECOSYSTEM SERVICES (PES) FINANCE MODEL FOR COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION INTO NEW VILLAGES, WITH A FOCUS ON MUONG LA NATURE RESERVE (MLNR), (2) FURTHER IMPROVE COMMUNITY-BASED GIBBON MONITORING CAPACITY, WITH THE SPECIFIC INTENTION OF FURTHERING KNOWLEDGE ON GIBBON FEEDING ECOLOGY, HABITAT AND OCCUPANCY, (3) BUILD AN EFFECTIVE AND ACTIVE TRANSBOUNDARY COALITION OF PRACTITIONERS TO SHARE DATA, LESSONS AND BEST PRACTICES, TO MEASURABLY IMPROVE GIBBON CONSERVATION OUTCOMES, AND, (4) BEGIN IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SPECIES ACTION PLAN IN VIETNAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE TO RELEASE REHABILITATED ORPHANED AND CONFISCATED ORANGUTANS BACK TO THE WILD, INTO SAFE PROTECTED AREAS. THE PROJECT WILL CONTINUE TO SUPPORT THE SUCCESSFUL CREATION OF NEW, FULLY WILD, VIABLE POPULATIONS OF BORNEAN ORANGUTANS, BY INCREASING THE UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROCESSES OF ADAPTATION OF EX-CAPTIVE ORANGUTANS IN THE WILD; DEVELOPING LONG-TERM MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND IDENTIFYING THE DYNAMICS OF NEWLY-ESTABLISHED ORANGUTAN POPULATIONS, WHILST FOSTERING THE PARTICIPATION AND PARTNERSHIP OF LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES WILL, (1) EVALUATE ORANGUTAN REINTRODUCTION SUCCESS AND IDENTIFY FACTORS THAT IMPACT INDIVIDUAL ADAPTATION AND SURVIVAL, AND, (2)  IMPLEMENT NEW TECHNIQUES TO ENABLE LONG-TERM MONITORING OF THE NEW ORANGUTAN POPULATIONS.

THIS PROPOSAL COVERS THE NEXT 2-YEARS OF THIS PROJECT, DURING WHICH TIME BORNEO NATURE FOUNDATION (BNF) WILL DEVELOP A PROPOSED PROTECTED AREA (PA) PLAN, BASED UPON THE RESULTS OF THE ECOLOGICAL AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC SURVEYS, TO BE SOCIALIZED WITH COMMUNITY AND GOVERNMENT STAKEHOLDERS, ADAPTED ACCORDINGLY AND PRESENTED FOR THE DESIGNATION OF PROTECTED AREA STATUS. MANAGEMENT WILL INCLUDE THE PREPARATION OF SHORT-, MEDIUM- AND LONG-TERM MANAGEMENT PLANS, BOUNDARY-MARKING, ESTABLISHING PROTECTION UNITS, DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINABLE LIVELIHOOD INITIATIVES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF REVENUE-GENERATING ACTIVITIES. THROUGH THIS PROGRAM BNF WILL ENCOURAGE EXPANDING THE NATIONAL `SOCIAL FORESTRY PROGRAM', TO CREATE MORE COMMUNITY-MANAGED FORESTS WHERE POSSIBLE, AND WORK TO ACHIEVE PROVINCIAL PA STATUS IN KEY AREAS OF FOREST HABITAT. THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROTECT UP TO 100,000 HECTARES OF LOWLAND RAINFOREST HABITAT IN SOUTHERN BORNEO WITH OVER 2,000 WILD ORANGUTANS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT BNF WILL DEVELOP AN ORANGUTAN CONSERVATION PLAN FOR THE RUNGAN FOREST, BY ADOPTING A LANDSCAPE APPROACH TO CONSERVATION PLANNING AND WORKING CLOSELY WITH COMMUNITY, GOVERNMENT AND INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS. PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE TO, (1) DEVELOP A PROTECTED-AREA PROPOSAL FOR THE RUNGAN LANDSCAPE, AND, (2) IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT WITHIN RUNGAN LANDSCAPE.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF SAN DIEGO.  THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO STRENGTHEN ACTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THE PROPOSED EBO NATIONAL PARK'S CORE GORILLA HABITAT BY ''CLUBS DES AMIS DES GORILLES'' (CAG), TRADITIONAL CHIEFS, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) REGULAR COMMUNITY RECCE TRANSECT PATROLS WITHIN THE GORILLA HABITAT; 2) RECORDING THREATS TO GORILLAS AND CHIMPANZEES; 3) CONTINUING THE PROCESS OF ESTABLISHING A ''NO-GO ZONE'' IN THE CORE GORILLA HABITAT; 4) ENGAGING COMMUNITIES THROUGH MULTI-FACETED OUTREACH ACTIVITIES; 5) SUPPORTING SMALL-SCALE LIVELIHOOD-BASED PROJECTS IN THE THREE COMMUNITIES; AND 6) CONDUCTING ANNUAL FOREST-WIDE RECCE TRANSECT SURVEYS TO MONITOR THREATS, CHIMPANZEES AND OTHER ENDANGERED SPECIES.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SOCIETY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO DETERMINE THE CURRENT STATUS, DISTRIBUTION AND THREATS TO CHIMPANZEES IN CRITICAL SITES IN WESTERN UGANDA; AND TO DEVELOP CONSERVATION ACTIONS TO STRENGTHEN CHIMPANZEE CONSERVATION IN THE SURVEYED SITES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCTING A CHIMPANZEE CENSUS IN SELECTED SITES, INCLUDING ANALYZING, MAPPING AND REPORTING RESULTS; 2) CONDUCTING REFRESHER TRAINING FOR RESEARCH ASSISTANTS; AND 3) CONDUCTING A STAKEHOLDER MEETING TO DISSEMINATE CENSUS RESULTS, DEVELOP CONSERVATION INTERVENTIONS, AND IDENTIFY IMPLEMENTING PARTNERS.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SOCIETY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES IN RWANDA'S NYUNGWE NATIONAL PARK BY DETERMINING THEIR CURRENT NUMBERS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) PLANNING AND CARRYING OUT SYSTEMATIC LINE TRANSECT SURVEYS OF THE PARK; 2) TRAINING WCS AND RWANDAN PARKS AUTHORITY STAFF IN SURVEY PROTOCOLS AND DATA ANALYSIS; 3) UPDATING THE PARK'S GENERAL MANAGEMENT PLAN AND RESEARCH PRIORITIES; 4) ORGANIZING A STAKEHOLDER WORKSHOP TO PRESENT THE SURVEY RESULTS; AND 5) SUBMITTING A PAPER ON THE SURVEY FINDINGS FOR PUBLICATION IN A PEER-REVIEWED JOURNAL.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE REMAINING WESTERN CHIMPANZEE POPULATIONS IN GHANA BY PROVIDING DATA ON THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF THE SPECIES TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF PRAGMATIC CONSERVATION ACTIONS, AND FOSTER COMMUNITY SUPPORT.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MAX PLANCK INSTITUTE FOR EVOLUTIONARY ANTHROPOLOGY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO MONITOR ANTHROPOGENIC EFFECTS ON MOUNTAIN GORILLAS IN BWINDI IMPENETRABLE NATIONAL PARK, UGANDA. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONTINUING LONG-TERM MONITORING OF GROUP SIZE, STRUCTURE, AND BIRTH AND MORTALITY RATES OF HABITUATED GROUPS; 2) QUANTIFYING THE TIME HABITUATED GORILLA GROUPS SPEND OUTSIDE OF THE PARK, AND SPEND CROP RAIDING; 3) QUANTIFYING THE FREQUENCY OF HABITUATED GORILLA GROUPS CROSSING THE PARK ROAD; 4) STRENGTHENING NATIONAL CAPACITY FOR SCIENCE-BASED CONSERVATION AND TOURISM MANAGEMENT; AND 5) CONDUCTING CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND COMMUNITY OUTREACH.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE MAX PLANCK INSTITUTE FOR EVOLUTIONARY ANTHROPOLOGY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO USE RESEARCH AND CAPACITY BUILDING TO SUPPORT TOURISM AS A CONSERVATION STRATEGY FOR CRITICALLY ENDANGERED WESTERN GORILLAS IN LOANGO NATIONAL PARK, GABON. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) MONITORING THE IMPACT OF TOURISM ON A HABITUATED GORILLA GROUP AND ON NON-HABITUATED GORILLAS; 2) CONTINUING HABITUATION OF A SECOND GORILLA GROUP; 3) CONDUCTING LONG-TERM GORILLA BEHAVIORAL ECOLOGY RESEARCH; 4) COORDINATING WITH THE GABONESE WILDLIFE AUTHORITY (ANPN) ON MANAGEMENT, SURVEILLANCE FOR ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR TOURISM; AND 5) STRENGTHENING NATIONAL CAPACITY FOR SCIENCE-BASED CONSERVATION AND ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT BY TRAINING GABONESE STAFF.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE LIVERPOOL JOHN MOORES UNIVERSITY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT PROTECTION OF EASTERN CHIMPANZEES BY ESTABLISHING BASELINE DATA ON THE EFFECT OF ANNUAL BURNING ON CHIMPANZEE HABITAT AND BEHAVIOR IN WESTERN TANZANIA, AND DISSEMINATING FINDINGS FOR INTEGRATION INTO FIRE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) IDENTIFYING LANDSCAPE FEATURES THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH BURNING PATTERNS ACROSS THE GREATER MAHALE ECOSYSTEM; 2) IDENTIFYING  AREAS OF OVERLAP BETWEEN BURNING AND CHIMPANZEE HABITAT USE; 3) IDENTIFYING THE EFFECT OF BURNING ON VEGETATION AND ESTABLISHING MONTHLY MONITORING; AND 4) SPONSORING AND TRAINING A POST-GRADUATE MSC STUDENT IN GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS AT THE UNIVERSITY OF DAR ES SALAAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO ENABLE THE EFFECTIVE AND SUSTAINABLE PROTECTION OF GRAUER'S GORILLAS BY LOCAL COMMUNITIES BY IMPROVING COVERAGE AND EFFECTIVENESS OF BIOMONITORING IN COMMUNITY RESERVES ADJACENT TO MAIKO NATIONAL PARK, AND BY IMPLEMENTING BIOMONITORING IN THE ITEBERO SECTOR OF KAHUZI BIEGA NATIONAL PARK (KBNP), EASTERN DRC. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) OPTIMIZING COMMUNITY BIOMONITORING METHODOLOGY; 2) EQUIPPING AND TRAINING 40 NEW BIOMONITORING PATROL TEAM MEMBERS; 3) DEPLOYING FIVE NEW MONTHLY COMMUNITY BIOMONITORING PATROLS IN THE COMMUNITY RESERVES; AND 4) DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING A CONTEXT-SPECIFIC COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAM.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION OF NIGERIA-CAMEROON CHIMPANZEES IN MBAM & DJEREM NATIONAL PARK (MDNP), CAMEROON.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) ASSESSING DISTRIBUTION, ABUNDANCE AND STATUS OF CHIMPANZEES IN THE PARK; 2) PROVIDING ACTIVE AND PASSIVE PROTECTION THROUGH PERMANENT PRESENCE OF RESEARCH TEAMS AT THE GANGA RESEARCH STATION; 3) IMPROVING CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT OF MDNP BY PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING IN FIELD RESEARCH PROTOCOLS AND ANTI-POACHING STRATEGIES; 4) CONTINUING COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AT THE NEWLY-ESTABLISHED MBAKAOU WILDLIFE CENTER; AND 5) USING MDNP AS A HUB TO HOST AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR CAMEROONIAN AND EQUATORIAL GUINEAN COLLEGE STUDENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS 2-YEAR PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE SCIENTIFIC DATA TO INFORM THE FUTURE ASSESSMENT OF THE GORILLA CARRYING CAPACITY OF VOLCANOES NATIONAL PARK, RWANDA. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) INVESTIGATING THE COMPOSITION, DIVERSITY, AND SEASONAL VARIATION OF DIETS OF THREE MOUNTAIN GORILLA GROUPS OUTSIDE OF THE KARISOKE SECTOR; 2) ASSESSING AND COMPARING THE NUTRITIONAL COMPOSITION OF FREQUENTLY CONSUMED GORILLA FOOD PLANTS; AND 3) CALCULATING MONTHLY AND ANNUAL HOME RANGES OF THE GROUPS AND DETERMINING THE IMPORTANCE OF EACH HABITAT TYPE TO GROUPS' HOME RANGES.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CAMEROON WILDLIFE CONSERVATION SOCIETY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE CONSERVATION STATUS OF CHIMPANZEE POPULATIONS WITHIN THE NEWLY-CREATED DOUALA-EDEA NATIONAL PARK BY DETERMINING THEIR CURRENT ABUNDANCE AND DISTRIBUTION, AND THE THREATS THEY FACE.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCTING A CHIMPANZEE CENSUS AND DATA ANALYSIS; AND 2) CONDUCTING A THREATS ANALYSIS USING DIRECT FIELD OBSERVATION, BUSHMEAT MARKET SURVEYS, STAKEHOLDER INTERVIEWS, AND A FIELD ASSESSMENT OF EXTRACTIVE ACTIVITIES.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ALLIANCE POUR LA CONSERVATION DES GRANDS SINGES EN AFRIQUE (GSAC ALLIANCE). THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE CONSERVATION OF CENTRAL AFRICAN APES BY SUPPORTING THE DEVELOPMENT OF SIX LOCAL NON-GOVERNMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS (NGOS). ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) IMPROVING TECHNICAL CAPACITIES THROUGH TARGETED TRAINING; 2) IMPROVING THE PROFILE OF APE CONSERVATION NGOS THROUGH PARTICIPATION IN REGIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL MEETINGS AND CONFERENCES; AND 3) HOLDING A GSAC ALLIANCE COORDINATION MEETING.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE AFRICA NATURE INVESTORS FOUNDATION. THE PURPOSE OF THIS 1-YEAR PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE VITAL POPULATION OF NIGERIA-CAMEROON CHIMPANZEES IN NIGERIA'S GASHAKA-GUMTI NATIONAL PARK THROUGH STRENGTHENING OF RANGER LAW ENFORCEMENT, MONITORING, AND SURVEILLANCE CAPABILITIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) EVALUATING THE CURRENT RANGER FORCE AND SELECTING THE 50 MOST QUALIFIED RANGERS; 2) EQUIPPING AND TRAINING SELECTED RANGERS; AND 3) ESTABLISHING RANGER PATROLS IN THE CRITICAL SOUTHERN 1,000 SQ. KM SECTOR OF THE PARK.
